review.title: Qualitative detection of oil adulteration with machine learning approaches
review.abstract: The study focused on the machine learning analysis approaches to identify the adulteration of 9 kinds of edible oil qualitatively and answered the following three questions: Is the oil sample adulterant? How does it constitute? What is the main ingredient of the adulteration oil? After extracting the high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) data on triglyceride from 370 oil samples, we applied the adaptive boosting with multi-class Hamming loss (AdaBoost.MH) to distinguish the oil adulteration in contrast with the support vector machine (SVM). Further, we regarded the adulterant oil and the pure oil samples as ones with multiple labels and with only one label, respectively. Then multi-label AdaBoost.MH and multi-label learning vector quantization (ML-LVQ) model were built to determine the ingredients and their relative ratio in the adulteration oil. The experimental results on six measures show that ML-LVQ achieves better performance than multi-label AdaBoost.MH.

metadata.title: Qualitative detection of oil adulteration with machine learning approaches

sections.text: The study focused on machine learning analysis to qualitatively identify the adulteration of 9 types of cooking oil and answered the following three questions: Is the oil sample adulterated? How is it composed? What is the main component of the adulterated oil? After extracting the High Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC) to triglyceride from 370 oil samples, we applied Adaptive Boosting with Multi-Stage Hamming Loss (AdaBoost.MH) to distinguish the adulteration from the Support Vector Machine (SVM). Furthermore, we considered the adulterated oil and the pure oil samples as such with multiple labels and only one label each. Then, we used the Multi-Stage AdaBoost.MH and Multi-Stage Learning Vector Quantization (ML-LVQ) to determine the ingredients and their relationship in the adulteration.

sections.heading: 2. Materials and methods
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.1. Reagent and Chemicals
sections.text: The acetonitrile and dichloromethane were sourced from Merck (Darmstadt, Germany) for the Gradient Solution. Water was purified on a Milli-Q system (Millipore, Bedford, MA, USA). All other reagents were of analytical high quality unless otherwise stated.

sections.heading: 2.2. Sample preparation
sections.text: Nine types of cooking oil were obtained from Henan and Shandong Provinces (China), including soybean oil, palm oil, sesame oil, maize oil, peanut oil, sunflower oil, rice bran oil, rapeseed oil and cotton oil (see Table 1). Adulterated oil consists of 4 types of base oil (soybean, peanut, sunflower and sesame oil), which is adulterated with other 5 types of oil in the set percentage range between 5% and 99%. The data set contains 370 examples with 1607 dimensions linked to a series of timestamps.

sections.heading: 2.3. Instrumentation and chromatographic conditions
sections.text: The chromatogram data of the cooking oil was obtained from the HPLC system using a vacuum degasser, an auto-sampler and a double pump of the Agilent 1100 series (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA).The HPLC system was equipped with a reverse phase C18 analysis column measuring 250 mm x 4.6 mm (5 µm particle size).The column temperature was maintained at 70 ° C. The injected sample volume was 20 µL. The mobile phases A and B consisted of acetonitrile or dichloromethane (35: 65), respectively, and the flow rate was set to 1,000 µL / min.

sections.heading: 2.4. Data analysis
sections.text: In our work, we apply three types of methods to analyze the oil samples in machine learning: First, we apply the classification method to distinguish the adulterated oil from the pure oil; second, we consider the pure oil as the sample with only one label and the adulterated oil as one with multiple labels; and then we revert to the multi-stage learning method, which can not only assess whether the oil is pure or adulterated, but also effectively detect the composite components of the adulterated oil. Finally, we use MLLVQ to forward analyze the relative ratio of the different components in the adulterated oil; and, as a reference, we also give the analysis results to the most advanced methods, including SVM and PCA, where SVM Burges (1998) constructs a hyperplane or a series of hyperplanes in high-dimensional space to maximize the margin.

sections.heading: 2.4.1. Adulteration detection with binary AdaBoost.MH
sections.text: The classic AdaBoost.MH Schapire & Singer (1999) is introduced as follows: Consider a marked dataset D = {(xn, tn)} N = 1. We often use + 1 and -1 to label the oil sample as adulterated oil or pure oil.The following classification model builds by using a nonlinear function from the input data to the real number.By using the sign f (x) we can predict the unknown sample x as falsification if f (x) > 0 otherwise is pure oil.AdaBoost.MH 1 combines the final hypothesis by repeatedly invoking the weak learner in a series of rounds in a different data distribution. In each round, the weights of each wrongly classified example are increased and the weights of each correctly classified example are reduced, so that the next new classifier focuses on the previously correct examples.

sections.heading: 2.4.2. Detection of ingredients in non-pure oil with multi-label AdaBoost.MH
sections.text: In the context of multi-label classification, we can consider the oil sample as an example with multiple labels. Thus, the pure oil and adulterated oil are provided with only one label or more than one label. In predicting the unknown oil sample, the multi-label classification algorithm can not only detect the components of the adulterated oil, but also detect the adulterated oil like the binary AdaBoost.MH in Section 2.4.1. We will introduce the multi-label algorithm Schapire & Singer (1999) below. Consider a labeled datasetD = (xn, tn) n = 1, where tn is the subset of L = {1, 2, · ·, L} instead of {+ 1, − 1}. Successful multi-label learning will result in a ranking of possible labels to classify the results in the label1Schapire & Singer.

sections.heading: 2.4.3. Analysis of the relative ratio on components with ML-LVQ
sections.text: It is worth noting that the multi-step labeling AdaBoost.MH can predict the components of the adulterated oil, but cannot effectively determine the relative ratio of the ingredient in the adulterated oil. For example, although we know that the adulterated oil consists of soybean oil and peanut oil, it is not clear whether the soybean oil in the peanut oil is adulterated or the peanut oil in the soybean oil is adulterated. ML-LVQ Jin et al. (2012) effectively considers the ranking problem when assigning multiple labels to the example. ML-LVQ extends LVQ to the problems with multiple labels where the minimal classification error on the labels can approximate the rank loss. ML-LVQ minimizes the upper limit of the ranking loss due to stochastic labeling. When the n-th training example is given in the prediction metry, two prototypes from the positive class for the respective label are selected.

sections.heading: 3. Results and Discussion
sections.text: For 370 oil samples, the benchmarks of all algorithms in the oil data set were determined by 10 runs of 5-fold cross-validation to avoid the randomness introduced by the data set partition. 1. For each run, the data set was randomly divided by layered samples into five subsets of approximately the same size. We maintained the same classifications for all learning algorithms. 2. Each of five subsets was used as a test set and the remaining data was used for the training. 5 subsets were used for the rotational tests to evaluate the performance of machine learning methods. 3. During each training process, the training parameters were determined as follows: First, we kept 1 / 3 of the training parameters ready for validation by layered samples, while the model parameters were estimated on the remaining 2 / 3 of the data (the distribution of training data is the same for all learning algorithms). After selecting training parameters, the training parameters that provide the highest accuracy for each training dial were used.

sections.heading: 3.1. Overview of HPLC spectra of edible oil
sections.text: Fig. 1 shows the chromatographic data of two types of pure oil and their mixture. There is a lot of overlap between these samples except for a small difference in the web tip. The similarity of the spectra makes detection with the craft characteristics so difficult, and then we resort to machine learning techniques to detect the difference.

sections.heading: 3.2. Evaluation Measures
sections.text: Accuracy is a widely used measure used in the classification algorithm to evaluate performance. In terms of evaluating multi-label algorithms, we use both the dichotomy and the ranking Tsoumakas et al. (2010) with respect to the accuracy of data from multiple labels. The dichotomy measures the average difference between the actual and the predicted set of labels, including the macro averaging and the microaverage of F1 (mac-F1 and mic-F1). The ranking measures the average difference between the true ranking and the predicted ranking, including the error and the average accuracy (avg-prec). We also specify the accuracy measurement to contrast with previous binary classification problems. Finally, we supply the detectrate (detectrate) to evaluate the predicted set of labels or not.

sections.heading: 3.3. Detection results with AdaBoost.MH classification model
sections.text: SVM is a classic classification approach used in the chemometries Cogdill & Dardenne (2004) and Diagnosis C-omaka et al. (2007). In our thesis, we make comparisons to SVM and AdaBoost.MH. Specifically, we run AdaBoost.MH with and without PCA pre-processing to analyze the effects of PCA. The optimal model parameters were found using the strategy described at the beginning of this section. We selected T from {100, 200, 300, 400, 500} for AdaBoost.MH, where T is the number of stumbling blocks. SVM classifier with RBF kernel was implemented by the Bioinformatics toolbox in Matlab. We looked only at the compromise parameter C and kernel width, selecting both log2C and log2 γ.

sections.heading: 3.4. Detection results with multi-label learning algorithm
sections.text: We compared the performance of Multi-Label AdaBoost.MH and ML-LVQ = 7} 7 {9} QQ = 9 QQ = 99 QQ = 20 QQ = 32 QQ = 24 QQ = 24 QQ = 32 QQ = 32 QQ = 32 QQ = 24 QQ = 46 QQ = 44 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 98 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 Q = 99 Q = 99 Q = 99 Q = 99 Q = 99 Q = 99 Q = 99 Q = 99 Q = 99 Q = 99 Q = 99 Q = 99 Q = 10 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 10 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 10 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 10 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99 QQ = 99

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: The HPLC data of the cooking oil with its mixture were examined to answer the following questions: Is the oil sample adulterated? How is it composed? What is the main component of the adulterated oil? In our study, we used the practical AdaBoost.MH to determine that the oil sample is adulterated or not in order to achieve a higher accuracy than the state of the art SVM. Furthermore, AdaBoost.MH with PCA does not show the better performance than one without pre-processing, as PCA cannot guarantee class separation in terms of characteristics. Finally, we used the multi-label AdaBoost.MH and ML-LVQ to identify the ingredient and its ratio in the intake of the adulterated oil and the pure oil as examples with multiple labels or labels. Finally, the comparisons between the multi-label methods AdaBoost.MH and MLVQ for the quantification of these ingredients show that MLVQ is the least suitable in our 2008 detection method (also MLVL-promising).

sections.heading: 5. Acknowledgements
sections.text: This work is partially supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC) under grant number 61103138, no. U1204617 and the Innovative Funding of Henan University of Technology.

In most applications found in the literature of oil-adulteration detection, the multivariate statistical analysis like linear discriminant analysis (LDA) Lorenzo et al. MH) classification method to determine that the oil is adulterant or not in contrast with the support vector machine (SVM) that is widely applied in the oil authentication Caetano et al. (2007); Devos et al.

MH) classification method to determine that the oil is adulterant or not in contrast with the support vector machine (SVM) that is widely applied in the oil authentication Caetano et al. (2007); Devos et al. (2009). AdaBoost.

MH) classification method to determine that the oil is adulterant or not in contrast with the support vector machine (SVM) that is widely applied in the oil authentication Caetano et al. (2007); Devos et al. (2009). AdaBoost.MH is the combination of multiple weak classifiers, where each weak classifier related to an optimal feature implements the feature selection in some sense. The experimental results show that AdaBoost.MH achieves the superior performance than SVM. Meanwhile, it is easy-to-use for the practical application with only one parameter T and T is set to 100 enough to work well unlike SVM that implements the model optimization in the grid of two parameters. In addition, we also explored the role of the principal component analysis (PCA) preprocessing in AdaBoost.MH classification method and the empirical results demonstrate that AdaBoost.MH performs better when using all features because PCA doesn’t consider the class information and can not guarantee the class separation. Second, we regarded the samples of the pure oil and the adulterant oil as ones with one label and multiple labels, respectively. Then we could apply multi-label learning to detect the ingredients of the adulterant oil. We further analyzed the relative ratio of the components in the adulterant oil with multilabel learning vector quantization (ML-LVQ) Jin et al. (2012) although the multi-label AdaBoost.

MH) classification method to determine that the oil is adulterant or not in contrast with the support vector machine (SVM) that is widely applied in the oil authentication Caetano et al. (2007); Devos et al. (2009). AdaBoost.MH is the combination of multiple weak classifiers, where each weak classifier related to an optimal feature implements the feature selection in some sense. The experimental results show that AdaBoost.MH achieves the superior performance than SVM. Meanwhile, it is easy-to-use for the practical application with only one parameter T and T is set to 100 enough to work well unlike SVM that implements the model optimization in the grid of two parameters. In addition, we also explored the role of the principal component analysis (PCA) preprocessing in AdaBoost.MH classification method and the empirical results demonstrate that AdaBoost.MH performs better when using all features because PCA doesn’t consider the class information and can not guarantee the class separation. Second, we regarded the samples of the pure oil and the adulterant oil as ones with one label and multiple labels, respectively. Then we could apply multi-label learning to detect the ingredients of the adulterant oil. We further analyzed the relative ratio of the components in the adulterant oil with multilabel learning vector quantization (ML-LVQ) Jin et al. (2012) although the multi-label AdaBoost.MH can predict the labels of the oil samples Huo et al. (2012). Finally, The statistical analysis including the micro-F1, the macroF1, the average precision, the one-error, the accuracy and the detect rate measures gives the full comparisons between the multi-label AdaBoost.

As a reference, we also give the analysis results on the state-of-art methods including SVM and PCA, where SVM Burges (1998) constructs a hyperplane or set of hyperplanes in the high dimensional space to maximize the margin.
ML-LVQ Jin et al. (2012) considers the label ranking problem effectively when the example is assigned with multiple labels.
As for the evaluation of the multi-label algorithms, we use both of the bipartitions and the rankings Tsoumakas et al. (2010) with respect to the ground truth of multi-label data.
SVM is a classic classification approaches applied in chemometrics Cogdill & Dardenne (2004) and diagnosis Çomaka et al. (2007). In our work, we give the comparisons on SVM and AdaBoost.

We also note that our method can only detect the oil adulteration qualitatively unlike the least squares support vector machine (LS-SVM) Wu et al. (2008) which can measure the ingredients quantitatively.

metadata.abstractText: The study focused on the machine learning analysis approaches to identify the adulteration of 9 kinds of edible oil qualitatively and answered the following three questions: Is the oil sample adulterant? How does it constitute? What is the main ingredient of the adulteration oil? After extracting the highperformance liquid chromatography (HPLC) data on triglyceride from 370 oil samples, we applied the adaptive boosting with multi-class Hamming loss (AdaBoost.MH) to distinguish the oil adulteration in contrast with the support vector machine (SVM). Further, we regarded the adulterant oil and the pure oil samples as ones with multiple labels and with only one label, respectively. Then multi-label AdaBoost.MH and multi-label learning vector quantization (ML-LVQ) model were built to determine the ingredients and their relative ratio in the adulteration oil. The experimental results on six measures show that ML-LVQ achieves better performance than multi-label AdaBoost.MH.
metadata.creator: LaTeX with hyperref package
